turn.speaker: walter_e_dellinger_iii
turn.label: Mr. Walter E. Dellinger, III
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the court.
Title one of the Americans With Disabilities Act does more than merely prohibit hostile discrimination against individuals wi- with disabilities.

Congress recognized that an additional kind of discrimination is the failure of employers through indifference or whatever to undertake reasonable accommodations to the physical or mental limitations of otherwise qualified individuals.
As a result, this act does affirmatively require businesses to lift barriers that inhibit employment opportunities for those with disabilities.
The question here, though, is whether, in one particular respect, the act goes beyond a requirement that obstacles be cleared away.
The issue is this.

Where an employee is unable, because of a disability, to continue in his job, is that employee entitled to be placed in another position instead of a more senior fellow employee who would be entitled to the job under the normal operation of a bona fide seniority system? Now, this is not an easy question wha- but we believe that in the end a clear answer necessarily emerges from the act.
And that is this, that the act simply does not require an employer to override neutral selection criteria wholly unrelated to disability in choosing among applicants for a position.
And in particular it does not require the employer to set aside the normal operation of a bona fide seniority system.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Someone may get a job that they would a job where they would have preferred another...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: job.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: That's correct, but no one would lose their job...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: because of the reassignment.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, it depends.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, you could conclude that, but I think it's if you look at the statutory structure, if you looked at the list of reasonable accommodations, if you look at the governing regulations, all of these provisions explain how the equities are weighed...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: in the statutory...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: of them that shows that Congress envisioned not just putting some burden on the employer, but putting some burden on fellow employees?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: MS. CLAUDIA CENTER: Well, the...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: mentions vacancy only I mean, it mentions vacancy because nobody's nobody's hurt if there's a vacancy.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, the plain language of the statute requires that the employer provide reasonable accommodation.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, but if I reject that view of the statute on on the one I was taking, I'd still like to know what the response is to what I think is the main point, which is not the domino effect.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, if you disagree with our reading of the term, reasonable accommodation, the term st- still would require a case-by-case individualized analysis of whether it was reasonable in this situation, and what the petitioner wants is a per se rule for bona fide seniority policies.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: Say that your client could be bumped by someone who's more severely handicapped if he were in that position?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: I think that each of the handicapped employees would be entitled to reassignment to a vacant position.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: Well, but I it's my understanding that these positions are deemed open at some point.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well I think, then, that the the client would be the mo- more disabled individual would be entitled to reassignment.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: Well, not that's I think you've missed my point.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: There could be conflicting requests for accommodation, that's...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: correct.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: person be entitled to that position...

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: There would be a number of...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: ways to...

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: your argument?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: I don't believe that the more disabled employee would be entitled to bump the less-disabled employee.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: think that...

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Why? Because th- the employee that i- needs the accommodation continues to need the accommodation.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: But you could say that about the people who have the job inst- in the first instance, couldn't you?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: The person who had that position and had his or her life worked out, day care, et cetera, et cetera, also needed that position.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: So the argument's the same.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: But the argument is that there's a Federal law in this case that requires reasonable accommodation, including reassignment.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: Let me ask you this.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: He has a back impair- back impairment.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: What does that mean?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: He has an orthopedic disability.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Has it been established that he in fact qualifies as disabled, or is that something we're just assuming arguendo at this stage of the case?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: It's disputed.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask about a hypothetical that's running running through my mind.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Could you ask it one more time? I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It seems to me theoretically possible that the he is because of his disability, he's leaving a job that is a very attractive job for a nondisabled person.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But it does have the effect of giving a preference.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Sure, but...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: but preferring one to I mean, giving someone an adv- a benefit that someone else doesn't get, such as allowing them to do a certain job sitting down when everybody else has to do it standing up, or what-not, that doesn't disadvantage the others.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, it's true that in certain cases, providing the reassignment to the vacant position ends up giving a priority to the disabled employee over a nondisabled employee.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the reverse...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: that you you think reasonable, the word reasonable and reasonable accommodation requires examining what happens to other employees as well as a result of the accommodation, then you have a different question.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: And if you do decide that reasonable takes into account other employees, in this case the equities really favor Mr. Barnett, because Mr. Barnett is the one that faced job loss.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: I hate to belabor the point, Ms. Center, but the more disabled employee, someone who's severely disabled, if that person has to be accommodated and we only have has have to look at that person's needs in making our reasonableness determination, I don't understand why your client can't be bumped if he were in that position.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: If you pulled out reasonable?

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: And only and you limited that determination to th- the disabled person who has to be accommodated.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, if you pulled out reasonable in that way, I s- think there'd be a difficulty arguing it would be reasonable to disrupt another effective accommodation that's already in place.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: But that's then your argument is only different in slightly from the argument that you have to take into consideration the disruption that's caused in others' lives when you disrupt the seniority system.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, I think that the disruption, as we state in our brief, can be considered in the undue hardship defense.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: factors.

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: consider the disruption to your client in the undue hardship category?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, but aren't you saying that in the in the case that Justice Thomas poses you do consider the disruption to your client as well as the interest...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: of the more -- Okay.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Then why don't you do that across the board? In other words, why doesn't why shouldn't why don't you have to concede that reasonableness always takes into consideration the interest of other employees?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Because I think that's contrary to the structure of the statute.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but can you find any textual basis in the statute that says when you're dealing with comparative interests of two disabled people you consider the interests of both in determining what is reasonable, but when you're considering the comparative interests of a disabled person and others, you don't consider both?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I was...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: basis for that?

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Perhaps I'm still misunderstanding, but I was answering the question assuming that m- my reading of the statute was rejected and that we were looking at equities in the word...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: reasonable.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You weren't conceding it all right, just for argument.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do I misunderstand? So I thought you had agreed earlier that it would never be reasonable to bump another employee.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the reason you can't bump another employee is that that's unreasonable, is that...

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: bumping an individual.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: you've said, you're you're making of this statute in this respect something different from, in title seven, where you have past proven discrimination, so the employer may have to give a remedy, that remedy may adversely affect other people.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: criteria.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: case by case, I look at the record here, and it doesn't seem to me as if your client wants to prove anything.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, I think there are a number of items in the record that show that the actual disruption to the employer, as well as the impact on other employees, would have been extremely modest, and that retaining Mr. Barnett in the job he'd been successfully performing for years was would have been an entirely reasonable accommodation, if you want to pull out reasonable.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Isn't that a matter of proof.

turn.speaker: claudia_center
turn.label: Ms. Claudia Center
turn.text: Well, that's true, and there's certainly sufficient evidence under Reeves for our client to have a trial on that issue,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: should...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Center.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Thank you.
